title: Guy Mannering; or, The Astrologer - Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Another possible source of the plot--a more romantic origin,certainly--is suggested by Mr. Robert Chambers in "Illustrations of theAuthor of 'Waverley.'" A Maxwell of Glenormiston, "a religious andbigoted recluse," sent his only son and heir to a Jesuit College inFlanders, left his estate in his brother's management, and died.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: Glenormiston was smiling.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: The old CunzicNeuk had been demolished by Glenormiston, and Tammy, living in betterquarters, was studying to be a teacher at Heriot's.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: Bobby's a famous dog, with the freedom of Edinburghgiven to him, and naething will do but Glenormiston must show him to acompany o' grand folk at his bit country place.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: But Glenormiston was smiling, and these sharp witted slum bairnsexchanged knowing glances.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: Mr. Traill flashed a glance at Glenormiston.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: It was into this bare,whitewashed chapel that Glenormiston turned to get some restorationdrawings he had left on the pulpit.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: Glenormiston was pulling Bobby's silkily fringed ears thoughtfully.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: Glenormiston, coming from thecountry of the Ettrick shepherd, knew such lonely figures, and thepathos of old age and waning powers that drove them in to the poorquarters of towns.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: Glenormiston was a man after his own heart, and they were getting alongfamously; but, oh! it began to seem more and more unlikely that a LordProvost, who was concerned about such braw things as the restoration ofthe old cathedral and letting the sun into the ancient tenements, shouldbe much interested in a small, masterless dog.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: Such buried and forgottentreasure, Glenormiston explained, filled the entire south transept.

title: Greyfriars Bobby
author: Atkinson, Eleanor
snippet: Glenormiston wasstanding in a rear doorway of the cathedral near the Regent's Tomb,looking out into the sunny square of Parliament Close, when Mr. Trailland Bobby appeared.

title: Rab and his friends and other dogs and men,
author: Brown, John
snippet: There is no fear of failure if Glenormiston sets himself to organize a home for our destitute four-footed fellow-creatures, from whom we get so much of the best enjoyment, affection, and help.
